paper_title.en: Effect of air press treatment before killing on the delay of post-mortem of eel and Tilapia

description.en: effect of press treatment (PT) on the post-mortem of fish before killing was examined. The PT was carried out by increasing the air pressure from 2 to 5 ata (absolute pressure) underwater with living fish for 50 minutes. In the case of eels and tilapia, they consumed as much oxygen as 203.0, 88.3 mL/kg .h at 4.5 ata respectively, and the average of these values was 2.1 times as much as the value of the control at 1.0 atm. Their initial content of ATP in dorsal muscle after killing increased an average of 1.4 times as much as 6.9 and 4.1 mu mol/g of the control, and then the ATP content was held at a high level during storage at 3 degreesC. As a result, the times to full rigor-mortis became 78.0 h and 12.5 h, so that times were delayed 23.0 h and 6.0 h respectively. compared to the control values.

paper_title.en: Effect of Infection of Hypertonic Saline before Killing on Post-mortem Changes in Eels.
Relationship between critical water content and denaturation of myofibrillar protein in fish surimi

description.en:
Since equilibrium water content (We) was considered to decrease with the denaturation of fish muscle protein, critical water contents (Wc), which were obtained on the characteristic dehydration curve during dehydration with a low osmotic sheet, were measured to investigate the relationships between the denaturation of myofibrillar (Mf) protein and We in tilapia surimi during storage for 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 days at 0 degrees C. An inflection point was obtained in the falling rate period of logarithmic dehydration curve for the surimi, and it was named the second critical water content (Wc(2)). The Wc(2) decreased with decreases in MfCa(2+)-ATPase total activity and Mf solubility during storage. Positive high correlations between Wet and MfCa(2+)-ATPase total activity, and between Wc(2) and Mf solubility were obtained.
As a result, Wc(2) could be useful as an index for evaluating protein denaturation.

Effect of Specific Binding of High Density Lipoprotein to Eel Hepatocytes on Their Secretion of Lipoprotein(共著)
RELATION BETWEEN PROTEIN DENATURATION AND LIPID OXIDATION IN FISH MUSCLE DURING STORAGE AT LOW-TEMPERATURES

description.en:
We have reported previously that the rate of lipid oxidation due to POV (peroxide value) decreases with temperature and increases with lipid content in fish muscle. In the present paper, we investigated the relation between myofibrillar-protein (M(f)P) denaturation and lipid oxidation in muscles of sardine under various conditions during storage at low temperatures (0, -5, and -20 degrees C). The M(f)P denaturation in sardine muscle was determined by measuring M(f) (Ca)-ATPase activity as an indicator; it occurred rapidly at an early stage where lipid oxidation was still in the induced period during storage. The rate of denaturation was independent of lipid content in the fish muscle.
As a result, the relation between protein denaturation and lipid deterioration in fish muscle stored at low temperature was not recognized at an early stage of storage. Both phenomena appeared to occur independently.
